text:
Broadway 43 to 44th St.
Present site of Paramount Bldg.
Photograph by Brown Brothers
220 West 42nd St.
New York City
1903

Broadway, east side, south from 44th Street. Rector's, in the centre, and Schloss's, adjoining it, are about to be replaced by the Hotel Claridge. On the N.E. corner of 43rd Street is the Hotel Cadillac.

May, 1909.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, west side, south from and including 44th Street. This view also shows Seventh Ave., west side, south from but not including 44th Street. About 1930.

Times Photo Service.

238-244 and 246 West 44th Street, south side, between Broadway and Eighth Ave., showing the Little Theatre at No. 238-244. Adjoining same is a 4-story brownstone house that has given way to the present St. James Theatre; the entrance to same being here.

About 1920.

Mattie Edwards Hewitt Photograph.

The Hotel Claridge, Broadway at the S.E. corner of 44th Street. Below the Claridge is the Hotel Cadillac. About 1920.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

(1)
Hotel Astor, Broadway, west side, from 44th to 45th Streets.
Summer 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the hotel entrance.
1936.

Broadway, east side, south from 44th Street, showing also Seventh Avenue, east side, from 44th to 40th Streets. This picture was made on Armistice Day, during the two-minute silence, and shows the Times Square crowds standing hushed, the men with bared heads, as a bugler on a balcony of the Hotel Astor sounds "Taps." Notice the campaign poster on the Hotel Cadillac for Fiorello H. La Guardia, now a member of the House of Representatives. Mr La Guardia, the Republican candidate, has just been defeated in the mayoralty election by Mayor James J. Walker, now at the height of his popularity. A year earlier the Republicans had denied renomination to him for the House of Representatives, and he made a successful campaign on the Socialist ticket. Four years later, in 1933, he will be elected Mayor of New York, defeating the incumbent, Mayor John P. O'Brien, and former Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee. November 11, 1929.

International News.

The Criterion Theatre, Broadway at the N.E. corner of 44th Street. The building which houses the Criterion and New York theatres will be demolished in 1935, and in 1936 a new theatre will be located on the site.

October 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

160/158 West 44th Street, at and adjoining the S.E. corner of Broadway. The corner building No. 160, is the Hotel Claridge with its main entrance on Broadway.

August 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, northeast corner of 44th Street, north side, looking eastwards showing Loew's State Theatre.
NO RECORD OF PHOTOGRAPHY
August, 1935

West 44th Street, at the N.E. corner of Broadway, showing excavation where the former Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatres stood. Across clearance is shown Broadway, west side, at West 45th Street, with a portion of the Hotel Astor at the S.W. corner.

August 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

West 44th Street, south side, west from (No. 234) a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. and across the latter, showing two theatres the Little and the St. James. They bear respectively Nos. 238-244 and 246. This set consists of 2 views; a positive and a negative.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 44th Street, south side, west from (No. 234) a point midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. and across the latter, showing two theatres the Little and the St. James. They bear respectively Nos. 238-244 and 246. This set consists of 2 views; a positive and a negative.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 44th Street, north side, west from the Court, midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. to the latter, showing in the foreground two theatres, the Shubert and the Majestic. The aforementioned Court, whose southern terminus appears on the right is located at the rear of the Astor Hotel and runs northward to 45th Street. The theatres bear street numbers 223 and 245 respectively. This set consists of a positive and a negative view.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 44th Street, north side, west from the Court, midway between Broadway and Eighth Ave. to the latter, showing in the foreground two theatres, the Shubert and the Majestic. The aforementioned Court, whose southern terminus appears on the right is located at the rear of the Astor Hotel and runs northward to 45th Street. The theatres bear street numbers 223 and 245 respectively. This set consists of a positive and a negative view.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

(1) Broadway, east side, nqrth from West 44th to 45th Streets, and showing the demolition of the building housing the Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatres. July 6, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(2) A view of the S.E. corner of West 45th Street; the portion housing Loew's N.Y. Theatre. July 6, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same as No. 2; from a different angle, and showing also a view eastward on the south side of West 45th Street. July 6, 1935. P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, east side, north from West 44th Street, and showing excavation where the former Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatre stood. This view shows Loew's State (motion picture) Theatre entrance thru the 17-story Building, at the N.E. corner of West 45th Street, with the theatre building at it's rear.

August 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A portion of No. 1, and showing across excavation, the Lyceum Theatre (Nos. 157-149), with the 45th Street Exchange (Nos. 147-141) adjoining. Note the R.K.O. Building and R.C.A. Tower in the background.

August 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A view westward thru excavation, and showing the west side of Broadway, with the Hotel Astor thereon, with 44th Street on the left.

August 9, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Broadway, east side, south from West 45th to 44th Streets. This building containing two theatres and a roof garden, will be demolished and a new structure erected here in 1936.

June 17, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The occupant of the N.E. corner of West 44th Street; the Criterion Theatre.

West 44th Street, north side, east from (No. 141-139) a point midway between Broadway and Sixth Ave., and across the latter and showing the Columbia Radio Playhouse (formerly the Hudson Theatre) at No. 141-139; the Hotel Langwell (formerly the Hotel Gerard) at No. 129-23 and the Belasco Theatre at No. 121-111. All three of these are west of Sixth Ave., which is shown with its elevated line thereon. This set of 2 views consists of a negative and a positive.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 44th Street, north side, east from (No. 141-139) a point midway between Broadway and Sixth Ave., and across the latter and showing the Columbia Radio Playhouse (formerly the Hudson Theatre) at No. 141-139; the Hotel Langwell (formerly the Hotel Gerard) at No. 129-23 and the Belasco Theatre at No. 121-111. All three of these are west of Sixth Ave., which is shown with its elevated line thereon. This set of 2 views consists of a negative and a positive.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.

Broadway (Times Square), north from W. 44th Street. These W. P. A. photos are taken to show pavement conditions. The photographer's line of view is up 7th Avenue (which loses its identity between 42nd and 47th Streets); Broadway proper being on the right. These intersect at 45th Street. The Astor Hotel at the left, and the International Casino--Criterion Theatre Building at the right, occupy opposite frontages of the 44th Street blocks.

June 4, 1937
Views 1,2

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

Broadway (Times Square), north from W. 44th Street. These W. P. A. photos are taken to show pavement conditions. The photographer's line of view is up 7th Avenue (which loses its identity between 42nd and 47th Streets); Broadway proper being on the right. These intersect at 45th Street. The Astor Hotel at the left, and the International Casino--Criterion Theatre Building at the right, occupy opposite frontages of the 44th Street blocks.

June 4, 1937
Views 1,2

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

Broadway (Times Square), east side, from West 44th (right) to 45th (left) Street's, showing the new theatre and taxpayer erected on the site of the old Criterion and the New York Theatre. This new structure houses a new Criterion Theatre and the International Casino. The Wrigley sign above is quite distinctive and attracts great attention.

October 18, 1938

George D. Chinn

Broadway (Times Square) north from W. 44th Street.
1939
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

Broadway, e.s., betw. 44th-45th Sts.
The large building at right is Hammerstein's Olympia Theatre, later New York Theatre.

P.L. Sperr collection
Rec'd September 12, 1945
